content: The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include State Grants for Drug and Violence Prevention Programs. The Secretary reserves funds for grants to Guam, American Samoa, Virgin Islands, and Northern Mariana Islands, programs for Indian youth, national impact evaluation, and programs for Native Hawaiians. State allotments are also specified. The Secretary reserves funds for programs for Native Hawaiians and allocates state allotments based on population and previous funding received. The Secretary may reallot funds to a State if it cannot be used within two years. States receive a minimum of one-half of 1 percent of the total amount allotted. To receive funding under section 4111, the State's chief executive officer must submit an application to the Secretary. The application must describe how funds will be coordinated with other programs, include results of a needs assessment for drug and violence prevention, and assure cooperation with the Secretary for national impact assessments. The State's application for funding under section 4111 must include data on drug use and violence among youth, cooperate with the Secretary for national impact evaluations, and undergo peer review. "State programs under SEC. 4113 must include data on drug use and violence among youth, cooperate with national impact evaluations, and undergo peer review." The chief executive officer of a State must use allocated funds for drug and violence prevention programs. Administrative costs are limited to 5% of the total amount received. Grants or contracts must be used exclusively for prevention or education programs on the dangers of illegal drug use and underage drinking. The allocated funds for drug and violence prevention programs must be used exclusively for prevention or education programs on the dangers of illegal drug use and underage drinking. Misuse of funds will result in penalties including forfeiture and reimbursement. Grants or contracts awarded under this program will be subject to peer review. Each Federal penalty provision applies to individuals responsible for misapplication of funds. Grants or contracts under this subsection are subject to peer review. The chief executive officer of a State can carry out activities directly or through grants. Funds are used to award grants for drug abuse and violence prevention activities in partnership with law enforcement agencies and educational or community-based agencies. The curr_chunk discusses partnerships between law enforcement and educational agencies for drug abuse and violence prevention activities, including programs like Drug Abuse Resistance Education and Legal Lives. It also mentions before- and after-school activities as part of prevention efforts. "SEC. 4114. EVALUATION AND REPORTING." The Secretary conducts a biennial evaluation of national impact of programs combating violence in schools, collecting data on violence frequency and seriousness in elementary and secondary schools. The Secretary evaluates the national impact of programs combating violence in schools by collecting data on the frequency, seriousness, and incidence of violence in elementary and secondary schools. States are required to submit reports on the implementation and outcomes of their programs every third year. The CEO of the State must submit a report to the Secretary on the implementation and effectiveness of State programs under section 4113, including data on drug use and violence by youth in schools and communities. The report must be in a specified form, based on ongoing evaluation activities, and made available to the public. The Secretary will provide grants to organizations serving Native Hawaiians recognized by the Governor of Hawaii to administer programs for their benefit. Native Hawaiian is defined as individuals with ancestors native to Hawaii before 1778.
